questions.question_text: Which standard access control entry permits traffic from odd-numbered hosts in the 10.0.0.0/24 subnet?

discussion.content:
Option "B".

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildcard_mask

Any wildcard bit-pattern can be masked for examination. For example, a wildcard mask of 0.0.0.254 (binary equivalent = 00000000.00000000.00000000.11111110) applied to IP address 10.10.10.2 (00001010.00001010.00001010.00000010) will match even-numbered IP addresses 10.10.10.0, 10.10.10.2, 10.10.10.4, 10.10.10.6 etc. Same mask applied to 10.10.10.1 (00001010.00001010.00001010.00000001) will match odd-numbered IP addresses 10.10.10.1, 10.10.10.3, 10.10.10.5 etc
what is happening to Cisco?

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
you learn something new every day, even if you will never use it in real life -_-

comments.content:
This entry permits traffic from odd-numbered hosts in the 10.0.0.0/24 subnet. 

The odd-numbered hosts (1, 3, 5, ..., 253) will be permitted, while the even-numbered hosts (0, 2, 4, ..., 254) will be denied.

discussion.content:
Answer is B.
A is not correct, would allow 10.0.0.0 or 10.0.0.1
C is not correct, would allow only 10.0.0.1 (wildcard 0.0.0.0 same as 'host')
D is not correct, would allow any even IP: x.x.x.0

comments.content: D is not correct because you have to specify a wildcard mask, not a subnet mask in an ACL.

discussion.content: Ah.. this brings back memories :D

comments.content: it's mostly to test your understanding of it, not really used in enterprise networks, but yeah, it's an interesting one to play around with :)

Thanks for you link, first time I see a wildmask to split between even-IP-addresses and odd-IP-addresses
access-list 101 permit ip any 10.10.10.0 0.0.0.254 -> even
access-list 102 permit ip any 10.10.10.1 0.0.0.254 -> odd
thx for the link
Best article ever !

discussion.content:
"B"
https://www.networkfuntimes.com/using-wildcard-masks-to-filter-odd-or-even-numbered-ip-addresses-juniper-junos-cisco-ios/
Basically, use the sequence number to add the entry to the access list so the list will be processing without interrupting

A. Uses the wrong Wildcard mask
B. Creates a new ACL but we only need to modify the existing one
C. If it is ineffective, the permit statement will be placed at the end of the ACL after the 'deny IP any any' entry. We need to place it before the 'deny all traffic' entry.

The correct answer is D

D is correct
you don't have to read all the answers, just noticed that D is the only one with a sequence number

D.

The ACE needs to be before the deny any ACE, or it won't be processed.
D is correct since question is asking you to modify not create a new access group.
if i change answer D sequence number to 15. will it work ?

comments.content: yes, as long as above 20.
also, the question says "modify EGRESS..." so B wouldn't be correct because it involves creating a new access-list, not modifying the existing one

discussion.content:
Correct answer is D.
B would also work but there would be a short disruption of traffic flow.

given answer is correct, 
for more expalanation the sequence number should be less than 19.
The given answer is correct
Since question is about modifying the 'EGRESS' acl, option D is correct.
The given answer is correct
The given answer is correct (C) as the configuration is blocking traffic to the control plane of the appliance using Control Plane Policing (CoPP).

comments.content: Transit traffic is data plane traffic.

discussion.content:
A and B are wrong because the policy is applied only on a single interface (Gig 0/1), this means traffic entering the router from the other interfaces remains unaffected.

B is also wrong because the ACL denies the SSH traffic. This means the policy CoPP_SSH will be applied on all traffic except SSH traffic (we want the complete opposite).
D is wrong because it is directed to transit traffic not management traffic (SSH in our case)
and the syntax is also wrong. 
Correction:
control-plane
 service-policy transit Copp_SSH
C is correct, it applies the policy on all SSH traffic entering the router
correct
C is correct
Not that either is the correct answer, but can anyone spot the difference between answer A and B?

comments.content: OK, found it thanks to discussion. A has permit 22, B has deny 22.
do you still see the 350-401 exam on the site? i can't find it, it says 404 error for all the cisco exams.

discussion.content: Another spot the difference challenge

comments.content: transit keyword = through router

NOPE

C) =Traffic generated by ROUTER that matches access list CoPP_SSH is policed.
D) =Traffic passing through ROUTER that matches access list CoPP_SSH is policed.

just a small correction:
C) = traffic RECEIVED by the ROUTER that matches access list CoPP_SSH is policed.
This is because the policy-map is applied using 'input' keyword.

discussion.content: C and D are the same??

The correct answer is A
permit tcp any any eq 22

comments.content: its C, please review this topic.
They all say that, except for B.

questions.question_text: What is a VPN in a Cisco SD-WAN deployment?

comments.content: @examShark Thanks mate !

discussion.content: Provided answer is correct

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Each VPN can have its own policies, routing, and security configurations, allowing different types of traffic to be securely transported over the SD-WAN fabric while maintaining isolation from other VPNs.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

C - From Cisco:

[...] VPN Segmentation: Traffic isolation is key to any security strategy. Traffic that enters the router is assigned to a VPN, which not only isolates user traffic, but also provides routing table isolation. This ensures that a user in one VPN cannot transmit data to another VPN unless explicitly configured to do so. When traffic is transmitted across the WAN, a label is inserted after the ESP header to identify the VPN that the user’s traffic belongs to when it reaches the remote destination. <<<<< C IS CORRECT>>>>>

Cisco SD-WAN Design Guide
SOURCE: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/SDWAN/cisco-sdwan-design-guide.html

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer.
anyone can enlight me where the B answer is wrong? thank you

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Ref: Cisco SD-WAN (Viptela) Configuration Guide, Release 18.1

“…
Segmentation (VPN) Overview

This article illustrates the segmentation and VPN capabilities of the Viptela overlay network solution.

Network segmentation has existed for over a decade and has been implemented in multiple forms and shapes. At its most rudimentary
level, segmentation provides traffic isolation. The most common forms of network segmentation are virtual LANs, or VLANs, for Layer 2
solutions, and virtual routing and forwarding, or VRF, for Layer 3 solutions.
…”

A. common exchange point between two different services

Wrong answer.

B. attribute to identify a set of services offered in specific places in the SD-WAN fabric

Wrong answer.

C. virtualized environment that provides traffic isolation and segmentation in the SD-WAN fabric

Correct answer.

D. virtual channel used to carry control plane information

Wrong answer.

Selected Answer: C
voting. provided answer is correct.
The correct answer is C, the VPN service is not alway related with "Secure", into MPLS architecture is used for provide isolated traffic without "Secure" component, same as SD-WAN.
the V in VPN is for virtual.A vpn is a secure encrypted tunnel that does provide traffic segmentation so the answer is C 100%

choices.D: virtual channel used to carry control plane information
choices.C: virtualized environment that provides traffic isolation and segmentation in the SD-WAN fabric
choices.B: attribute to identify a set of services offered in specific places in the SD-WAN fabric
choices.A: common exchange point between two different services
